Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Milesian Fikellura pottery neck-amphora; beige slip; exterior: painted decoration consisting of komos scene (from left, part of leg of male figure running to left; second male with only head and feet missing, holding oinochoe and running to right; at centre, part of a dinos on a stand; at right, right arm holding an oinochoe and part of rump of third male figure, to left); dot rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.303.1899 and GR.302.1899. Schaus lists the sherd as belonging to the Altenburg Painter. According to Cook's classification system, the sherd belongs in the Cambridge Group (named after this and the other sherds from the same vessel). The human figures are rudimentary but resemble those from the Altenburg Group, see Cook 1933-1934 pls. 5, 6, 11c, for the group's name piece Altenburg 191 amphora.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 60, pl. VI, no. 12c)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 36, no. 10, pl. XVIII, no. 10)
Schaus 1986 / Two Fikellura Painters (p. 254, no. 19, pl. 14d)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 135, no. 632)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 246, no. 4) (Incorrectly labelled as part of the Altenburg Group)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GF.019)
